DOC.TEXT: Blue chips steadied, but the rest of the stock market continued to slump today amid persistent worries about the future course of the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 56.10 points in the past two sessions, recovered 3.20 to 2,700.73 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 2 to 1, however, in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 501 up, 1,000 down and 477 unchanged. Analysts said the latest economic reports from the government hadn't done much to pull the market out of its recent slide, induced to a great extent by worries about the real estate market and mortgage debt. The Labor Department reported that the consumer price index rose 0.4 percent in November, or at an annual rate of 4.9 percent. That appeared to put a new obstacle before any fresh moves by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Separate government figures showed a 4.7 percent decline in housing starts last month. Brokers said that left stocks in the grip of recession fears and of talk that a slump in business conditions might be exacerbated by a weak market for homes and other real-estate properties. A few recently depressed mortgage and regional banking stocks staged a rebound. Federal National Mortgage rose 1[ to 32\, and Bank of New England gained { to 8. Other bank stocks were mixed. Citicorp dropped ] to 26{; Chase Manhattan rose [ to 32; J.P. Morgan lost } to 39~, and Bankamerica was up | at 24{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .52 to 189.65. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.36 at 368.50. Volume on the Big Board came to 160.44 million shares with an hour to go.
